children.name: sth you give to sb on a special occation or to say thank you
gift
children.definition: sth that you give sb, for example to thank them or because you like them, especially on a special occasionSYN present:
examples: The earrings were a gift from my aunt.
gift of
a generous gift of £50
gift from
In the hall was a magnificent vase, which was a gift from a Japanese businessman.
It was a gift to the US from the Chinese people.
gift for
I bought this CD as a gift for Jane, but she’s already got it.
RegisterIn everyday English, especially in British English, people usually saypresentrather thangift:
These were apresentfrom my boyfriend.

children.name: give somebody a gift
examples: We gave her a gift on her birthday.

children.name: receive a gift
examples: He received a gift from his aunt.

children.name: accept a gift
examples: Sam accepted the gift on behalf of the school.

children.name: make somebody a gift of somethingformal
children.definition: give someone something as a gift
examples: Johnson made her a gift of a book.

children.name: wrap
children.definition: up
examples: a giftShe had bought and wrapped gifts for children in hospital.

children.name: shower somebody with gifts
children.definition: give someone a lot of gifts
examples: He showered her with gifts and exotic holidays.

children.name: exchange gifts
children.definition: give someone a gift at the same time as they give you a gift
examples: We exchange gifts on Christmas Day.

children.name: a birthday gift
examples: The camera had been a 21st birthday gift from his parents.

children.name: a wedding gift
examples: Some people prefer to give cash as a wedding gift.

children.name: a
examples: Christmas giftBefore 1940, most people did not wrap Christmas gifts.

children.name: a free gift
children.definition: something that a shop or business gives you
examples: If you spend over £50, you get a free gift.

children.name: the perfect/ideal gift for somebody
examples: This book is the perfect gift for anybody who’s interested in birds.

children.name: a suitable gift
examples: What do you think would be a suitable gift for a 10-year-old boy?

children.name: a small gift
examples: Here’s a small gift to show our appreciation for all your hard work.

children.name: a generous gift
examples: Her colleagues presented her with a generous gift when she retired.

children.name: an expensive gift
examples: He was always showering Louise with expensive gifts.

children.name: a lavish gift
children.definition: a large, impressive, or expensive gift
examples: She received lavish gifts of jewellery and clothes.

children.name: a parting gift
children.definition: a gift that you give someone when you leave/say goodbye
examples: She brought him a parting gift.

children.name: an unwanted gift
examples: You can take any unwanted gifts to charity shops.

children.name: a gift idea
examples: Here is another gift idea with children in mind.

children.name: a gift shop
examples: The gift shop was well stocked with souvenirs.

children.name: present
children.definition: sth you give someone on a special occasion or to thank them for sth:
examples: I’m looking for a present for Mark.
present for
He got a lot of expensive presents for his 21st birthday.
‘What’s this?’ ‘It’s a present for Valerie - she needs cheering up.’
present from
The watch was a present from my mother.
COMMON ERRORS
►Do not say 'unpack a present'. Sayopen a present.

children.name: give somebody a present
examples: He gave everyone a present.

children.name: give something as a present
examples: I was given this book as a present.

children.name: buy somebody a present
children.definition: alsoget somebody a presentinformal
examples: I want to buy a present for Lucy but I'm not sure what she'd like.|Did you get Bill a birthday present?

children.name: get a present
children.definition: receive a present
examples: Children soon learn to enjoy giving presents as well as getting them.

children.name: wrap a present
examples: She spent the afternoon wrapping Christmas presents.

children.name: open/unwrap a present
examples: Can we open our presents now?

children.name: exchange presents
children.definition: give each other a present
examples: We always exchange Christmas and birthday presents.

children.name: a birthday present
examples: Thanks for the birthday present.

children.name: a
examples: Christmas presentWhat would Dad like as a Christmas present?

children.name: a wedding present
examples: His wedding present to her had been a diamond necklace.

children.name: sth that you get when you win
prize
children.definition: sth that is given to someone who is successful in a competition, race, game of chance etc : giải thưởng
examples: In this month’s competition you couldwinaprizeworth £3,000.

children.name: win a prize
children.definition: alsotake a prize
examples: She won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1938.|Ms Brolls also took the prize for best individual speaker.

children.name: get a prize
children.definition: alsoreceive a prizeformal
examples: The winner gets a prize.|If your letter is published, you will receive a £5 prize.

children.name: share a prize
examples: They will share the first prize of £500.

children.name: give
children.definition: somebody
examples: a prize(alsoaward (somebody) a prizeformal)A prize will be given for the best-decorated egg.|Four years later he was awarded the Erasmus Prize.

children.name: a prize goes to somebody
children.definition: they get it
examples: The fiction prize goes to Carol Shields.

children.name: first/second etc prize
examples: She won first prize in a poetry competition.

children.name: the top prize
examples: The film won the top prize at the Berlin Film Festival.

children.name: a consolation prize
children.definition: one given to someone who has not won
examples: The runner-up will get a consolation prize of a camera.

children.name: the booby prize
children.definition: one given as a joke to the person who comes last
examples: The cake I made for the competition was so bad I got the booby prize.

children.name: a cash prize
examples: There's a $5,000 cash prize for the winner.

children.name: a prize winner
examples: Congratulations to all the prize winners!

children.name: prize money
examples: The players are demanding an increase in prize money.

children.name: a prize drawBritish English
children.definition: a competition in which people whose names or tickets are chosen by chance win prizes
examples: He won the car in a prize draw.

children.name: prize for
examples: The prize for best photography has been won by a young Dutch photographer.
Scientists from Oxford shared the Nobel Prize for Medicine in 1945.

children.name: cup
children.definition: a special silver or gold container, shaped like a largecupwith two handles, that is given to the winner of a sports competition:

children.name: present the cup to sb
examples: The Queen presented the cup to the captain of the winning team.
The president of the club came topresentthecupto the winners.

children.name: medal
children.definition: a flat piece of metal, usually shaped like a coin, that is given to someone who has won a competition or who has done something brave : huy chương
examples: She won a gold medal at the last Olympics.
The two boys were awarded medals for bravery.

children.name: win a medal
examples: They won a medal at the Chelsea Flower Show.

children.name: take a medal
children.definition: win a medal
examples: German runner Stephan Freigang took the bronze medal.

children.name: get a medal
children.definition: alsoreceive a medalformal
examples: She received a medal from the Society of Arts.

children.name: give somebody a medal
examples: He was given a medal for his courageous actions.

children.name: be awarded a medal
examples: The book was awarded the Carnegie Medal.

children.name: a gold medal
children.definition: for first place
examples: He won the gold medal in Athens in 2004.

children.name: a silver medal
children.definition: for second place
examples: She was awarded the silver medal for the 100 metres.

children.name: a bronze medal
children.definition: for third place
examples: Morrell took the bronze medal in the long jump.

children.name: a medal winner
examples: Johnson was a silver medal winner at the Olympic Games.

children.name: trophy
children.definition: an object or special cup that is given to the winner of a race, game, or competition, especially in sports:chiến tích
examples: The winner went to receive her trophy.
walls lined with banners and athletic trophies
Football League/Masters/Heisman etc Trophy(= the name given to a particular competition for which the prize is a trophy )
They became the first British team to win a major European trophy.

children.name: jackpot
children.definition: the largest amount of money that can be won in a game of chance: giải độc đắc
examples: ▪ The jackpot is worth $1 million this week.

children.name: hit the jackpotwin it
examples: ▪ Unemployed roadsweeper Mickey Reid hit the jackpot when his £4 Lotto ticket won him £1.8m.

children.name: gold
children.definition: ( alsogold medal) a small disc of gold which is given to the person who wins a competition, especially in a sport
examples: He's running so well, surely he'll take the gold.

children.name: silver
children.definition: ( alsosilver medal ) a small disc of silver, or a metal that looks like silver, which is given to the person who comes second in a competition, especially in a sport
examples: Britain won (a) silver/a silver medal in the javelin.

children.name: bronze
children.definition: ( alsobronze ˈ medal) a small round piece of bronze given to a person who finishes third in a competition
examples: Hegota bronze in the high jump.

children.name: reward
children.definition: money that is offered to people for helping the police to solve a crime or catch a criminal : tiền thưởng
examples: reward of
A reward of $20,000 has been offered.
reward for
a reward for information leading to the capture of the murderers
adjectives

children.name: offer a reward
children.definition: alsoput up a rewardinformal
examples: The store has offered a £500 reward for information leading to a conviction.

children.name: claim a reward
examples: He contacted the police, hoping to claim the reward money offered by the bank.

children.name: a £10,000/$500 etc reward
examples: The $100,000 reward Levitz’s family offered in the days after her disappearance still stands.

children.name: a large/substantial reward
examples: Despite a substantial reward being offered, the painting has never been found.

children.name: reward money'
examples: Anyone who gives me the information that leads to an arrest will get the reward money,' he repeated|.

children.name: reward
children.definition: sth, especially money, that you get because you have done something good or helpful or have worked hard →prize,benefit: phần thưởng
examples: The school has a system of rewards and punishments to encourage good behaviour.

children.name: great/big/high
examples: The rewards for those who invested at the right time are high.|Some athletes took drugs because the rewards were great and they thought they could get away with it.

children.name: little reward
examples: They have to work very hard for very little reward.

children.name: financial/economic reward
children.definition: alsomonetary rewardformal
examples: It’s a difficult job, but the financial rewards are considerable.|I’m not doing it for monetary reward.

children.name: material rewards
children.definition: money or possessions that you get
examples: They think money and material rewards are more important than quality of life.

children.name: tangible rewards
children.definition: things that are obviously worth having
examples: The prize motivates people by offering them the prospect of a tangible reward for their efforts.

children.name: rich rewards
children.definition: great rewards
examples: Top athletes can expect rich rewards if they win.

children.name: personal reward
examples: I admire people who help the poor for no personal reward.

children.name: get/receive your reward
examples: If you work hard, you will get your reward.

children.name: reap rewards
children.definition: get them
examples: She is now reaping the rewards of all her hard work.

children.name: bring rewards
children.definition: cause someone to get rewards
examples: Winning the title brings huge financial rewards.

children.name: deserve a reward
examples: The team have worked really hard and deserve some reward.

children.name: reward for (doing) something
examples: Parents often give their children rewards for passing exams.

children.name: reward of
examples: The parents of the missing boy are offering a reward of £10,000.

children.name: award
children.definition: 1sth such as a prize or money given to someone to reward them for something they have done :
examples: The movie has won a number of awards.
an award-winning restaurant
award for
the award for best student
2sth, especially money, that is officially given to someone as a payment or after a legal decision:
the teachers’ pay award
an award for unfair dismissal
win an awardCaprio won the award for best actor.|an award-winning novel
a film/music/poetry etc awardthe annual British music awards

children.name: get/receive an award
examples: He is the youngest person ever to receive the award.

children.name: give somebody an award
examples: The award is given each year to the best new artist.

children.name: present somebody with an award
children.definition: give someone an award at a formal ceremony
examples: She cried when she was presented with her award.

children.name: be nominated for an award
children.definition: alsobe up for an awardinformal
examples: (= to be chosen as one of the people, films etc that could receive an award )Four films have been nominated for the award.|The book is up for an award.

children.name: pick up/scoop up an award
children.definition: to get an award – used especially in news reports
examples: Angelina Jolie scooped up the award for best actress.

children.name: the award goes to somebody/something
children.definition: that person, film etc is chosen to receive it
examples: The poetry award went to Lisa Mueller for ‘Alive Together'.

children.name: the highest award
examples: The Victoria Cross is Britain’s highest military award.

children.name: a top award/a major award
examples: The restaurant has won several top awards.|Their design won a major award at a Paris exhibition.

children.name: a special award
examples: He received a special award for his work as a movie director.

children.name: a prestigious award
children.definition: very well-respected
examples: The Nobel Prize is regarded as the most prestigious award in the world.

children.name: a literary award
examples: The book was nominated for a major US literary award.

children.name: an awards ceremony
examples: My parents wanted to be at the awards ceremony.|The stars are gathering for the annual awards ceremony.

children.name: an award winner
examples: The award winners will be announced in December.

children.name: an award scheme
examples: British English The league started a new award scheme for young players.
